/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%201.jpeg: Dominic, Nick, and Gretta arrive in Danbury, Connecticut, visiting Nick's twin sister, Anya.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: Behind schedule, we were in and out of Danbury lickety split, leaving later that night.
Dominic and his 1983 Mercedes wagon turned biodiesel, 3 bikes atop the auxiliary fuel tank.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%204.jpeg: Having pilfered waste cooking oil, we used thrift store t-shirts to filter it.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%206.jpeg: Filtered cooking oil is left up up the roof, then emptied into the auxiliary fuel tank.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: Arriving at Frank and Dolores, near Iona, Nova Scotia.
Dinner with Frank and Dolores, friends of friends.
Heading out from Frank & Dolores
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%2012.jpeg: Scenery on our first day of riding. Idyllic, no?
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: A bulging tube, wrapped in paper to reinforce it, is inserted into Dominic's tire.
Clearly, that didn't hold.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%2024.jpeg: At the end of this road, we thought we'd find a spot to camp to wait out the rain and deal with tire issues.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: A surgical approach was needed to fix Dominic's tire.
It worked, but not very long, exploding before we could get out of camp.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%2030.jpeg: Bikes are strewn around in apparent chaos, but there is a plan!
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%2032.jpeg: A tandem bike is built to get around having only 3 functioning wheels for two bikes. It did move, but having two pivot points made it ultimately impossible to ride.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: We made friends with a local up on the highway, who kindly brought us into Sydney, a town big enough to have a bike shop!
To form knee warmers for Nick!
Gretta, an excellent fiddle player, tries her hand at Sydney's giant fiddle, built 3 years earlier.
Camping to warm fire in a neighborhood outside North Sydney.
Pizza on the ferry from Nova Scotia to Newfoundland.
Checking out the beautiful views before heading belowdecks.
Pizza and cards on the 7 hour ferry ride.
Nick rubs in the round trouncing he delivers with a photo.
We arrived at Channel-Port aux Basque (Newfoundland) at 11:30pm, then headed out the next morning.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%2052.jpeg: Dominic freshens up in a lake along our bike ride.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: Bike maintenance on our first real day of riding.
The weather is holding much better in Newfoundland!
Dusk at campsite.
A beautiful photo, though one altered by the camera settings to add yellow.
Aaron, the friend we "brought home from the (gas) bar" (what they call gas stations), central gathering points in the otherwise vast expanse of Newfoundland's single main highway.
Dominic tries to nap after we saw our friend off at 6am, but it was only 7am.
Gretta takes a hit of maple syrup before wrestling Dominic.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%2060.jpeg: She tries to get him up...
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: But it doesn't go so well.
Camping outside Corner Brook
Nick reads in his tent.
Dominic and Gretta find convenient head rests.
Dominic and Gretta cut a rug.
Ryan hosts us in Corner Brook the next day.
Strawberries!
Wild raspberries!
Tart cherries!
These cherries eventually made delicious syrup for our pancakes.
On the road.
Woody Point lighthouse
Pinks clouds cover the bay.
Bidding farewell to Woody Point, the water taxi takes us across the bay to Norris Point.
/media/Map%20with%20Arrows.jpeg: Ferries connect various points on this map of Newfoundland.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%2099.jpeg: Gorgeous sunset at our camp site, right on the water.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20114.jpeg: An upside down arch on top of the arch.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20102.jpeg: Pitcher plants abounded in this rocky, peaty terrain.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20101.jpeg: The pitcher plant has some food to digest.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20122.jpeg: It wasn't safe to get much closer to this massive moose.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20103.jpeg: A bird alights on Dominic's hand.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: The picture of the man climbing a sheer face was an exaggeration, but not much of one.
A seemingly endless scramble up steep rocks!
Summiting!
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20124.jpeg: Our primary cooking device, a space efficient pressure cooker.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: Dominic, eating in style.
Loading up the pressure cooker.
Another dish, which may not look appetizing, but was assuredly delicious.
Popcorn!
Shepherd's pie, delicious (and vegan!) in Corner Brook.
The traditional Touton, doughy biscuits fried and then covered in molasses.
Heading down the road to Burgeo, a 150-km stretch with no towns along the way.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20140.jpeg: Vantage point from one of the many sweeping hills.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: Finally arrived in Burgeo, on the southwestern coast of Newfoundland.
View from Man o' War Hill on Ramea, an island town of 462 southeast of Burgeo.
Sunset.
Feasting with Jim and Judie, some folks we'd communicating with on couchsurfing.com prior to arriving in Ramea.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20115.jpeg: One of Nick's spokes was sheared in two after his pannier flew into it--a combination of poor strap design and uneven Newfie roads.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20120.jpeg: We sewed and sealed the bag with shoe goo.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20117.jpeg: We used bailing wire to reconnect the spoke, then true the wheel.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: Rebuilding Nick's axle, which unbeknownst to us had fractured at some point.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20155.jpeg: A fishing town and outport community, Grand Bruit, only reachable by ferry. We camped on the dock in the storage house.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20153.jpeg: This good boy selected the largest stick he could find to play fetch with. Note the "road" we were on, barely 4 feet wide.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: We splurged on pizza for the ferry ride back to Nova Scotia. Yum.
Waking up on our last day, Dominic's tent was sopping wet.
No, really wet.
The rain, having returned to greet us for our riding again in Nova Scotia, last all night, turning our campsite into a shallow marsh.
But at least it was convenient to wash our hands.
And our dishes!
After arriving back with Frank and Dolores, the terminus of our trip, we harvested blackberries and apples nearby and made pie!
Bidding Frank and Dolores farewell before hitting the road in Dominic's greasemobile.
